choices: The comic is funny because the astronaut doesn't know how to count properly and is embarrassed when corrected by the more knowledgeable orange-haired character.

The humor stems from the fact that every number system is "base 10" in its own representation, creating a paradoxical conversation where both characters believe they're talking about different systems.

The comic is satirizing how scientists overcomplicate simple tasks - counting to 10 shouldn't require discussion of mathematical base systems, showing how academics make everyday life unnecessarily complex.
Because the alien doesn't know what base 4 is.
The joke is that the fake Monkey King is exposed because he owns numerous cheap, knock-off earbuds, while the real Sun Wukong has genuine, expensive Apple AirPods, highlighting consumer culture.
The humor comes from identifying the fake Monkey King based on him possessing six earbuds, while the real one has the standard amount.
The comic is funny simply because it mixes an ancient Chinese legend with modern technology (wireless earbuds), creating an absurd anachronism.
The humor lies in Buddha's surprisingly mundane solution ('check their bags') to a legendary problem, bypassing any need for divine powers or insight to identify the imposter.
